title: AWS Accounts Guidelines
text:
Congratulations on receiving your AWS Student Account! Please review the following guidelines to ensure appropriate and responsible use:    Budget Limit  Each account is provisioned with a $100 budget for academic projects. If you believe your work will exceed this budget, please discuss it with your supervisor before incurring any additional costs. Your supervisor will contact Tech-Hub to get this limit raised. 
Responsible Usage  Use these resources strictly for authorised academic purposes. Any misuse—such as prohibited content, unlawful activities, or activities in breach of University policies—may result in immediate suspension or further disciplinary action. 
Monitoring  Account usage and spending may be monitored. If your usage approaches the $100 limit, consider scaling down non-essential services or terminating unused resources. 
Support and Queries  If you have any questions about the services, or need help with budget management, contact your supervisor or Tech-Hub.  If you anticipate needing additional budget or special resources (e.g., GPU instances for machine learning), consult your supervisor first. 
No Personal Gain  Only use the AWS account for University-related work, such as coursework, academic projects, or research. Commercial or private ventures are strictly prohibited. 
Data Security  Never store sensitive or confidential data (e.g., personal information, financial records, or licensed datasets) on AWS without proper authorisation.  Follow any University data protection requirements (including GDPR regulations, if applicable) when uploading, sharing, or transferring data. 
Access Management  Keep your login credentials secure; do not share your AWS credentials with anyone, including peers or collaborators.  Use the principle of least privilege when assigning permissions to services or users—grant only those permissions necessary to complete your task. 
Housekeeping  Regularly check and terminate any unused services or instances to avoid unnecessary costs.  Use AWS cost monitoring features and alerts to stay informed about your spending and resource usage.  Backup and Version Control  Implement regular backups for critical data and source code, particularly for work that cannot be easily reproduced.  Utilise version control (e.g., GitLab) for your projects where possible, ensuring you maintain local copies or separate repositories to prevent data loss. 
Account Lifecycle  Please notify Tech-Hub when you are finished with your account and no longer need it so that we can shut it down and not incur additional costs.

title: Tutorials
text:
This fundamental AWS Cloud course provides a comprehensive introduction to AWS services, architecture, security, pricing, and best practices. Designed for individuals across various non-technical roles, such as sales, marketing, legal, and business analysis, the course builds foundational AWS knowledge and helps prepare learners for the AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner exam. Participants will explore key AWS concepts, including cloud computing models, core AWS services like compute, storage, and databases, security best practices, and cost management strategies. The course also covers migration frameworks, monitoring tools, and the AWS Well-Architected Framework, ensuring a holistic understanding of AWS operations.
Delivered through video presentations, demonstrations, and knowledge checks, the course spans 7 hours and requires general IT business and technical knowledge. The curriculum is structured into modules covering topics such as networking, analytics, security, and pricing, culminating in a final assessment to reinforce learning. By the end of the course, learners will be equipped to articulate AWS benefits, navigate AWS infrastructure, identify cost-effective solutions, and leverage AWS services for various use cases, making it an ideal starting point for professionals entering the cloud domain.
Here

title: Tutorials
text:
AI Essentials
This introductory AWS Cloud course provides a foundational understanding of AWS services, architecture, security, pricing, and cloud concepts for individuals in non-technical roles. It is designed for professionals in sales, marketing, legal, business analysis, and project management who want to develop AWS Cloud knowledge and prepare for the AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner exam. The course covers key topics such as compute, storage, networking, security, and pricing models while introducing AWS migration strategies and best practices for cloud adoption.
Structured into multiple modules, the course includes video presentations, demonstrations, and knowledge checks over a 7-hour duration. Participants will learn about AWS global infrastructure, core services, security frameworks, cost management tools, and monitoring solutions like CloudWatch and CloudTrail. By the end of the course, learners will be able to identify AWS solutions for various business scenarios, understand cloud financial benefits, and navigate AWS certification pathways.
